items.message: High river levels today may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 22 January 2026. This information is correct as of 07:00 on Thursday 22 January 2026. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 34cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 26cm of water on the road. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the road. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. There are currently no issues on Earith causeway. We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
River levels remain high and flooding is possible on Thursday and overnight into Friday.

The river level at Huish Episcopi is stable at 8.90m. The drain level at Huish Episcopi is 7.52m and rising. Flooding will affect the Langport to Muchelney road if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Draycott road above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on local road closures. 

Pumping will start at Huish Episcopi and Westover stations once river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel will be opened once the river spillways stop running.

Unsettled conditions with some heavy spells of rain are forecast for the coming days. We continue to monitor the situation and staff are checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and don't walk, cycle or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12 midday on 23 January, or as the situation changes.

The Cuckmere River in Alfriston is high and rising following Wednesday's rain. In Hellingly, river levels are higher than normal, but slowly falling. Small amounts of rain are forecast each of the next five days, including Thursday morning, Thursday evening, and Friday morning. River levels will probably rise a small amount again. Minor flood impacts could return to gardens on Hammer Lane, Grove Hill, and Mill Lane, Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly, from 21:00 on 22/01/2026. Flood impacts could increase in Alfriston, potentially affecting North Street, Alfriston. River levels might not peak until Friday afternoon in Hellingly and until Saturday in Alfriston. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected, please take care when driving. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts Please do not drive through floodwater as this may cause bow waves. 
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 26 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Fittleworth on the Western River Rother
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding on Thursday. 
Flooding is expected on 22 January 2026 from 13:00, as a lot of rain (35mm) fell on Wednesday. 
Flood water will affect Fittleworth Mill, and nearby properties in Fittleworth. Flooding will be extensive in fields. The B2138 Lower Street road over the river at Fittleworth could be affected by flood water. Small amounts of rain are forecast each day from Thursday to Monday, but should not raise river levels significantly. River levels are expected to peak by 18:00 on 22/01/2026, at a similar height as on 16/01/2025. River levels will take a long time to fall. Flood risk might not reduce until the weekend. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Don't put yourself or others at risk . Avoid roads that flood (B2138 through Fittleworth). 
This message will be updated by 9:00PM on 22 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the South Winterbourne Valley
items.message:
Rising groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. 
Flooding is expected from 19th January 2026 onwards. 
Groundwater levels in West Dorset remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Winterbourne Abbas, Winterbourne Steepleton, Martinstown, Winterbourne Monkton, Winterbourne Herringston and Winterbourne Came. The groundwater level at the Kingston Russell borehole has risen to 116.56m, and is expected to rise further over the next few days. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected. Roads may be damaged by floodwater. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts . 
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 26 January 2026 or as the situation changes.
